div.head: Discourse 17.
div.ab:
The Philosophers have in many places made mention of four sorts of fire
necessary to the weewenaturall weeweworke, namely Lully, the Author of Scala, Ripley,
and many others: and to this end Raymund speaking of fires (Sayth Scala).
You must note, that here are contrary operations: because as the fire-
against nature dissolves the Spirit of a fixed body into the water of a-
cloud, and binds the body of a volatile spirit into a congealed earth, soeso
contrarywisecontrariwise the fire of nature congealescongeals the dissolved spirit of a fixed
body into a globous earth, and resolves the fixed body of a volatile-
Spirit by fire against nature, not into the water of a cloud, but into weewePhi
losophicall water. Ripley speaks more clearly of these fires in gate 3. thus:
There are four sorts of fires, which you ought to know, the weewenaturall, unna
turall, fire against nature, and weeweelementall, which kindlethkindles wood: These
fires weewewee use, and weewenoe more. Fire against nature ought to excruciate-
bodyes, that is the dragon, as I tell you, violently burning, as the fire of hell.
The fire of nature is the third menstruum, that fire is naturally in every
thing: Occasioned fire weewewee call weeweunnaturall, as the heat of ashes and baths
to putrefy: Without these fires you can bring nothing to putrefaction, where
by your matter may be separated, that it may at once be proportioned-
for a new conjunction: Make therefore a fire within in your weeweglasse, which
can weeweburne weewebodyes more effectually, than weeweelementall fire: these are their
sayings. They are indeed called fires, because they have a fiery virtue,-
the weewenaturall in coagulating, the weeweunnaturall in dissolving, the fire against
nature in corrupting, the weeweelementall in administringadministering the first heat and
motion: And there is a concatenated order observed in them, that the Se
cond may be incited by the first, the third by the second, the fourth by
the third and first together to action, soeso as that one is the agent, and
the other the patient, and the same both agent and patient in different
respect: That which is observed in iron rings or pillars held together by a
Magnet, and weewejoyned by weewemutuall contact, the same in these fires: for the
elementall weewedoth like the Magnet immit its virtue though the second
and third even to the fourth, and weewejoynes one to another by weewemutuall-
operations, and causethcauses them to stickestick together, till weeweinternall action be
effected amongst the uppermost: The first is weeweelementall fire indeed-
and name, the second is weeweaire or airy, the third weewewatry or of a Lunar na
ture, the fourth earthy: It is needlesseneedless to say any thing of the first,-
because it is weeweknowne to every mans eye and touch: The three other are
dragons, menstrua's, waters, Sulphurs, and weeweMercuryes: Dragons, because-
being participants of venenosity, they devouredevour serpents of their weeweowne
kind, frett and alter, that is, dissolve and coagulate weewebodyes incorporated-
and mixed with them: They are called Menstrua's, because the weewePhiloso
phicall infant is produced from them, and nourished therewith even to
its nativity: Lully in his weewebooke of the Quintessence, dist. 3. weewehath two-

Menstruums, the vegetable, and weeweminerall, Ripley in his weewePræface of the gates weewehath
three, which are really one and weewedoe agree: for the generation of the infant

is not of the substance but superfluity of the infant, and therefore to be-
separated: They are waters, because in fire they ShewShow a weewewatry nature, that
is, flowing and liquidity, which agrees with water: Manifest it is that the-
propertyesproperties of waters are different and weewewonderfull, whereof some weewedoe petrefypetrify, be
ing coagulated into very hard stones weewefitt for building: Very like these are the-
Philosophers weeweminerall waters, which weewedoe condense, and weeweturne into a stony con
sistence: They are weeweallso called Sulphurs because of the virtue of Sulphur,-
which they comprehend in them, for the Sulphur of nature is mixed and-
made one with the other Sulphur, and the two Sulphurs are dissolved by one,
and one is separated from two, and the Sulphurs are weewepræserved and contained
by Sulphur, as Yximidius in Turba weewesayth: Now what Sulphurs are Dardaris
there declares in these words: Sulphurs are Souls hidden in the fower elements,
which being extracted by art weewedoe naturally weewecontaine one another and are-
joyned together: if you can by water governegovern and purify well that which-
is hidden in the belly of Sulphur, that hidden thing meeting with its weeweowne-
nature rejoycethrejoices, even as water with its like. I will now tell you (Sayth Mosius
allso) what it is: the first indeed, which is fiery Argent vive, the second, the-
body compounded in it, and the third is the water of Sulphur, by which the
first is washdwashed, and dilacerated, and governed, till the weeweworke be accomplished:
That which is weewesayd of Sulphurs, the same may be understood of soeso-
many weeweMercuryes: For this weewesayth the same Mosius afterwards: Argent vive
Cambar is the Magnesia, but Argent vive or Auripigment is that Sulphur
which ascends from a weewemixd compound: But I will omittomit the inference of
more testimonyestestimonies, they being infinite and obvious to every man: These fourefour
fires are included as it were in Spheres and weeweorbes, that is, every one weewehath a
particular center, from which or to which their motion tends, but weeweneverthelesse
